description: DeltaPrime suffered a $4.75M exploit when attackers compromised an admin private key with upgrade privileges. They upgraded a pool contract to inject malicious code, then exploited the backdoored contract to drain funds through fake pair contracts and balance manipulation.
root_cause:
Single private key compromise allowed arbitrary contract upgrades without timelock or multi-sig

Key Weaknesses: Single private key controls upgrades; No multi-sig requirement; Missing timelock delay
attack_scenario:
Compromise admin key, upgrade pool to malicious implementation, exploit backdoor to drain funds

Attack Flow: Compromise admin private key via phishing/malware → Prepare malicious pool implementation with backdoors → Use compromised key to call upgradePool() → Upgrade pool proxy to malicious implementation → No timelock allows immediate execution → Create smart loan position via createLoan() → Obtain massive WETH flashloan from Balancer → Wrap ETH and deposit into manipulated pool → Call malicious swapDebtParaSwap() to manipulate balances → Call claimReward() with fake pair contract → Fake pair's claimRewards() inflates attacker balance → Withdraw inflated balance in real WETH → Extract $4.75M, repay flashloan, keep profit
fix_description: Implement multi-sig for all admin functions (3-of-5 minimum); Add timelock delay (24-48 hours) for upgrades; Use hardware security modules (HSMs) for keys
